TopicTitle: Accidentally deleted my most significant save on K.S.P.

Articles.Content: And that's an entire month of work gone.

:(

If you still have craft files, I think you could be forgiven for editing/ hyperediting things into place.

But, at least it will never happen again, as now you'll be motivated to start backing them up.

Yes, it's career so I'm using hyperedit to spam science so I can hopefully regain my once glorious space agency.

Things I had.

-14 flags on the Mun

-3 flags on Minmus

-one flag on Duna and a colony

-A space station

-Two deep space probes

-Probe landers on all the Muns of jool.

So, yea.
Or, sometimes, in the directory, if you right click, there is an option "undo delete". It should work as long as you haven't deleted anything else. If not, starting over is always fun
Or you look up how to undelete files on your operating system.

Did you wipe your entire install or did you just nuke the save?

This is a shamless plug, but I've been working on a tool (Jebretary) that puts all your craft and saves into a version control system. With it you can load up any past quicksave or autosave and you can revert craft back to how they where at each launch during their development. You interface with it via your browser (or from any web capable device on your LAN, 2nd machine, tablet, phone, whatever) and it has a v simple interface but under the hood it uses the git version control system. It tracks every single quicksave and autosave, but does it in a very space efficient way (thanks to git).

So long as you didn't wipe your entire save folder then it would have (if you'd been using it) been able to just restore your save with two clicks. If your interested click the link in my sig.
If you're on Windows, you can probably restore it from the Recycle Bin.
How does one, get to the recycling bin. I have no exact idea where it is in my maze of folders.
Windows Explorer (i.e. any folder link, e.g. My Documents) -> URL bar -> type "Recycle Bin" or at least the first few letters -> click the suggested link and BAM.
There is also software on the Net that can recover permanently deleted data, if you haven't written a lot of new data to the drive since the file was junked.
